books.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection

chapters.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:1
verses.text: Fragments of the Lost Work of Justin on the Resurrection   Chapter 1 — The self-evidencing power of truth.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:2
verses.text: The word of truth is free, and carries its own authority, disdaining to fall under any skilful argument, or to endure the logical scrutiny of its hearers.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:3
verses.text: But it would be believed for its own nobility, and for the confidence due to Him who sends it.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:4
verses.text: Now the word of truth is sent from God; wherefore the freedom claimed by the truth is not arrogant.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:5
verses.text: For being sent with authority, it were not fit that it should be required to produce proof of what is said; since neither is there any proof beyond itself, which is God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:6
verses.text: For every proof is more powerful and trustworthy than that which it proves; since what is disbelieved, until proof is produced, gets credit when such proof is produced, and is recognised as being what it was stated to be.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:7
verses.text: But nothing is either more powerful or more trustworthy than the truth; so that he who requires proof of this is like one who wishes it demonstrated why the things that appear to the senses do appear.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:8
verses.text: For the test of those things which are received through the reason, is sense; but of sense itself there is no test beyond itself.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:9
verses.text: As then we bring those things which reason hunts after, to sense, and by it judge what kind of things they are, whether the things spoken be true or false, and then sit in judgment no longer, giving full credit to its decision; so also we refer all that is said regarding men and the world to the truth, and by it judge whether it be worthless or no.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:10
verses.text: But the utterances of truth we judge by no separate test, giving full credit to itself.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:11
verses.text: And God, the Father of the universe, who is the perfect intelligence, is the truth.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:12
verses.text: And the Word, being His Son, came to us, having put on flesh, revealing both Himself and the Father, giving to us in Himself resurrection from the dead, and eternal life afterwards.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:13
verses.text: And this is Jesus Christ, our Saviour and Lord.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:14
verses.text: He, therefore, is Himself both the faith and the proof of Himself and of all things.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:15
verses.text: Wherefore those who follow Him, and know Him, having faith in Him as their proof, shall rest in Him.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 1:16
verses.text: But since the adversary does not cease to resist many, and uses many and divers arts to ensnare them, that he may seduce the faithful from their faith, and that he may prevent the faithless from believing, it seems to me necessary that we also, being armed with the invulnerable doctrines of the faith, do battle against him in behalf of the weak.

chapters.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 2

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 2 — Objections to the resurrection of the flesh.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 2:2
verses.text: They who maintain the wrong opinion say that there is no resurrection of the flesh; giving as their reason that it is impossible that what is corrupted and dissolved should be restored to the same as it had been.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 2:3
verses.text: And besides the impossibility, they say that the salvation of the flesh is disadvantageous; and they abuse the flesh, adducing its infirmities, and declare that it only is the cause of our sins, so that if the flesh, say they, rise again, our infirmities also rise with it.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 2:4
verses.text: And such sophistical reasons as the following they elaborate: If the flesh rise again, it must rise either entire and possessed of all its parts, or imperfect.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 2:5
verses.text: But its rising imperfect argues a want of power on God's part, if some parts could be saved, and others not; but if all the parts are saved, then the body will manifestly have all its members.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 2:6
verses.text: But is it not absurd to say that these members will exist after the resurrection from the dead, since the Saviour said, "They neither marry, nor are given in marriage, but shall be as the angels in heaven?" And the angels, say they, have neither flesh, nor do they eat, nor have sexual intercourse; therefore there shall be no resurrection of the flesh.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 2:7
verses.text: By these and such like arguments, they attempt to distract men from the faith.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 2:8
verses.text: And there are some who maintain that even Jesus Himself appeared only as spiritual, and not in flesh, but presented merely the appearance of flesh: these persons seek to rob the flesh of the promise.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 2:9
verses.text: First, then, let us solve those things which seem to them to be insoluble; then we will introduce in an orderly manner the demonstration concerning the flesh, proving that it partakes of salvation.

chapters.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 3 — If the members rise, must they discharge the same functions as now?  They say, then, if the body shall rise entire, and in possession of all its members, it necessarily follows that the functions of the members shall also be in existence; that the womb shall become pregnant, and the male also discharge his function of generation, and the rest of the members in like manner.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:2
verses.text: Now let this argument stand or fall by this one assertion.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:3
verses.text: For this being proved false, their whole objection will be removed.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:4
verses.text: Now it is indeed evident that the members which discharge functions discharge those functions which in the present life we see but it does not follow that they necessarily discharge the same functions from the beginning.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:5
verses.text: And that this may be more clearly seen, let us consider it thus.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:6
verses.text: The function of the womb is to become pregnant; and of the member of the male to impregnate.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:7
verses.text: But as, though these members are destined to discharge such functions, it is not therefore necessary that they from the beginning discharge them (since we see many women who do not become pregnant, as those that are barren, even though they have wombs), so pregnancy is not the immediate and necessary consequence of having a womb; but those even who are not barren abstain from sexual intercourse, some being virgins from the first, and others from a certain time.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:8
verses.text: And we see men also keeping themselves virgins, some from the first, and some from a certain time; so that by their means, marriage, made lawless through lust, is destroyed.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:9
verses.text: And we find that some even of the lower animals, though possessed of wombs, do not bear, such as the mule; and the male mules do not beget their kind.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:10
verses.text: So that both in the case of men and the irrational animals we can see sexual intercourse abolished; and this, too, before the future world.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:11
verses.text: And our Lord Jesus Christ was born of a virgin, for no other reason than that He might destroy the begetting by lawless desire, and might show to the ruler that the formation of man was possible to God without human intervention.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:12
verses.text: And when He had been born, and had submitted to the other conditions of the flesh,—I mean food, drink, and clothing,—this one condition only of discharging the sexual function He did not submit to; for, regarding the desires of the flesh, He accepted some as necessary, while others, which were unnecessary, He did not submit to.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:13
verses.text: For if the flesh were deprived of food, drink, and clothing, it would be destroyed; but being deprived of lawless desire, it suffers no harm.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:14
verses.text: And at the same time He foretold that, in the future world, sexual intercourse should be done away with; as He says, "The children of this world marry, and are given in marriage; but the children of the world to come neither marry nor are given in marriage, but shall be like the angels in heaven".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 3:15
verses.text: Let not, then, those that are unbelieving marvel, if in the world to come He do away with those acts of our fleshly members which even in this present life are abolished.

chapters.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 4

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 4 — Must the deformed rise deformed?  Well, they say, if then the flesh rise, it must rise the same as it falls; so that if it die with one eye, it must rise one-eyed; if lame, lame; if defective in any part of the body, in this part the man must rise deficient.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 4:2
verses.text: How truly blinded are they in the eyes of their hearts! For they have not seen on the earth blind men seeing again, and the lame walking by His word.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 4:3
verses.text: All things which the Saviour did, He did in the first place in order that what was spoken concerning Him in the prophets might be fulfilled, "that the blind should receive sight, and the deaf hear," and so on; but also to induce the belief that in the resurrection the flesh shall rise entire.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 4:4
verses.text: For if on earth He healed the sicknesses of the flesh, and made the body whole, much more will He do this in the resurrection, so that the flesh shall rise perfect and entire.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 4:5
verses.text: In this manner, then, shall those dreaded difficulties of theirs be healed.

chapters.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 5

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 5 — The resurrection of the flesh is not impossible.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 5:2
verses.text: But again, of those who maintain that the flesh has no resurrection, some assert that it is impossible; others that, considering how vile and despicable the flesh is, it is not fit that God should raise it; and others, that it did not at the first receive the promise.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 5:3
verses.text: First, then, in respect of those who say that it is impossible for God to raise it, it seems to me that I should show that they are ignorant, professing as they do in word that they are believers, yet by their works proving themselves to be unbelieving, even more unbelieving than the unbelievers.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 5:4
verses.text: For, seeing that all the heathen believe in their idols, and are persuaded that to them all things are possible (as even their poet Homer says, "The gods can do all things, and that easily;" and he added the word "easily" that he might bring out the greatness of the power of the gods), many do seem to be more unbelieving than they.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 5:5
verses.text: For if the heathen believe in their gods, which are idols ("which have ears, and they hear not; they have eyes, and they see not"), that they can do all things, though they be but devils, as saith the Scripture, "The gods of the nations are devils," much more ought we, who hold the right, excellent, and true faith, to believe in our God, since also we have proofs of His power, first in the creation of the first man, for he was made from the earth by God; and this is sufficient evidence of God's power; and then they who observe things can see how men are generated one by another, and can marvel in a still greater degree that from a little drop of moisture so grand a living creature is formed.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 5:6
verses.text: And certainly if this were only recorded in a promise, and not seen accomplished, this too would be much more incredible than the other; but it is rendered more credible by accomplishment.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 5:7
verses.text: But even in the case of the resurrection the Saviour has shown us accomplishments, of which we will in a little speak.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 5:8
verses.text: But now we are demonstrating that the resurrection of the flesh is possible, asking pardon of the children of the Church if we adduce arguments which seem to be secular and physical: first, because to God nothing is secular, not even the world itself, for it is His workmanship; and secondly, because we are conducting our argument so as to meet unbelievers.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 5:9
verses.text: For if we argued with believers, it were enough to say that we believe; but now we must proceed by demonstrations.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 5:10
verses.text: The foregoing proofs are indeed quite sufficient to evince the possibility of the resurrection of the flesh; but since these men are exceedingly unbelieving, we will further adduce a more convincing argument still, — an argument drawn not from faith, for they are not within its scope, but from their own mother unbelief,—I mean, of course, from physical reasons.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 5:11
verses.text: For if by such arguments we prove to them that the resurrection of the flesh is possible, they are certainly worthy of great contempt if they can be persuaded neither by the deliverances of faith nor by the arguments of the world.

chapters.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 6 — The resurrection consistent with the opinions of the philosophers.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:2
verses.text: Those, then, who are called natural philosophers, say, some of them, as Plato, that the universe is matter and God; others, as Epicurus, that it is atoms and the void; others, like the Stoics, that it is these four—fire, water, air, earth.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:3
verses.text: For it is sufficient to mention the most prevalent opinions.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:4
verses.text: And Plato says that all things are made from matter by God, and according to His design; but Epicures and his followers say that all things are made from the atom and the void by some kind of self-regulating action of the natural movement of the bodies; and the Stoics, that all are made of the four elements, God pervading them.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:5
verses.text: But while there is such discrepancy among them, there are some doctrines acknowledged by them all in common, one of which is that neither can anything be produced from what is not in being, nor anything be destroyed or dissolved into what has not any being, and that the elements exist indestructible out of which all things are generated.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:6
verses.text: And this being so, the regeneration of the flesh will, according to all these philosophers, appear to be possible.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:7
verses.text: For if, according to Plato, it is matter and God, both these are indestructible and God; and God indeed occupies the position of an artificer, to wit, a potter; and matter occupies the place of clay or wax, or some such thing.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:8
verses.text: That, then, which is formed of matter, be it an image or a statue, is destructible; but the matter itself is indestructible, such as clay or wax, or any other such kind of matter.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:9
verses.text: Thus the artist designs in the clay or wax, and makes the form of a living animal; and again, if his handiwork be destroyed, it is not impossible for him to make the same form, by working up the same material, and fashioning it anew.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:10
verses.text: So that, according to Plato, neither will it be impossible for God, who is Himself indestructible, and has also indestructible material, even after that which has been first formed of it has been destroyed, to make it anew again, and to make the same form just as it was before.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:11
verses.text: But according to the Stoics even, the body being produced by the mixture of the four elementary substances, when this body has been dissolved into the four elements, these remaining indestructible, it is possible that they receive a second time the same fusion and composition, from God pervading them, and so re-make the body which they formerly made.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:12
verses.text: Like as if a man shall make a composition of gold and silver, and brass and tin, and then shall wish to dissolve it again, so that each element exist separately, having again mixed them, he may, if he pleases, make the very same composition as he had formerly  made.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:13
verses.text: Again, according to Epicurus, the atoms and the void being indestructible, it is by a definite arrangement and adjustment of the atoms as they come together, that both all other formations are produced, and the body itself; and it being in course of time dissolved, is dissolved again into those atoms from which it was also produced.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:14
verses.text: And as these remain indestructible, it is not at all impossible, that by coming together again, and receiving the same arrangement and position, they should make a body of like nature to what was formerly produced by them; as if a jeweller should make in mosaic the form of an animal, and the stones should be scattered by time or by the man himself who made them, he having still in his possession the scattered stones, may gather them together again, and having gathered, may dispose them in the same way, and make the same form of an animal.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 6:15
verses.text: And shall not God be able to collect again the decomposed members of the flesh, and make the same body as was formerly produced by Him?.

chapters.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 7

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 7 — The body valuable in God's sight.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 7:2
verses.text: But the proof of the possibility of the resurrection of the flesh I have sufficiently demonstrated, in answer to men of the world.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 7:3
verses.text: And if the resurrection of the flesh is not found impossible on the principles even of unbelievers, how much more will it be found in accordance with the mind of believers! But following our order, we must now speak with respect to those who think meanly of the flesh, and say that it is not worthy of the resurrection nor of the heavenly economy, because, first, its substance is earth; and besides, because it is full of all wickedness, so that it forces the soul to sin along with it.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 7:4
verses.text: But these persons seem to be ignorant of the whole work of God, both of the genesis and formation of man at the first, and why the things in the world were made.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 7:5
verses.text: For does not the word say, "Let Us make man in our image, and after our likeness?" What kind of man? Manifestly He means fleshly man, For the word says, "And God took dust of the earth, and made man".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 7:6
verses.text: It is evident, therefore, that man made in the image of God was of flesh.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 7:7
verses.text: Is it not, then, absurd to say, that the flesh made by God in His own image is contemptible, and worth nothing? But that the flesh is with God a precious possession is manifest, first from its being formed by Him, if at least the image is valuable to the former and artist; and besides, its value can be gathered from the creation of the rest of the world.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 7:8
verses.text: For that on account of which the rest is made, is the most precious of all to the maker.

chapters.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 8 — Does the body cause the soul to sin?  Quite true, say they; yet the flesh is a sinner, so much so, that it forces the soul to sin along with it.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:2
verses.text: And thus they vainly accuse it, and lay to its charge alone the sins of both.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:3
verses.text: But in what instance can the flesh possibly sin by itself, if it have not the soul going before it and inciting it? For as in the case of a yoke of oxen, if one or other is loosed from the yoke, neither of them can plough alone; so neither can soul or body alone effect anything, if they be unyoked from their communion.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:4
verses.text: And if it is the flesh that is the sinner, then on its account alone did the Saviour come, as He says, "I am not come to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:5
verses.text: Since, then, the flesh has been proved to be valuable in the sight of God, and glorious above all His works, it would very justly be saved by Him.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:6
verses.text: We must meet, therefore, those who say, that even though it be the special handiwork of God, and beyond all else valued by Him, it would not immediately follow that it has the promise of the resurrection.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:7
verses.text: Yet is it not absurd, that that which has been produced with such circumstance, and which is beyond all else valuable, should be so neglected by its Maker, as to pass to nonentity? Then the sculptor and painter, if they wish the works they have made to endure, that they may win glory by them, renew them when they begin to decay; but God would so neglect His own possession and work, that it becomes annihilated, and no longer exists.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:8
verses.text: Should we not call this labour in vain? As if a man who has built a house should forthwith destroy it, or should neglect it, though he sees it falling into decay, and is able to repair it: we would blame him for labouring in vain; and should we not so blame God? But not such an one is the Incorruptible,—not senseless is the Intelligence of the universe.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:9
verses.text: Let the unbelieving be silent, even though they themselves do not believe.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:10
verses.text: But, in truth, He has even called the flesh to the resurrection, and promises to it everlasting life.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:11
verses.text: For where He promises to save man, there He gives the promise to the flesh.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:12
verses.text: For what is man but the reasonable animal composed of body and soul? Is the soul by itself man? No; but the soul of man.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:13
verses.text: Would the body be called man? No, but it is called the body of man.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:14
verses.text: If, then, neither of these is by itself man, but that which is made up of the two together is called man, and God has called man to life and resurrection, He has called not a part, but the whole, which is the soul and the body.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:15
verses.text: Since would it not be unquestionably absurd, if, while these two are in the same being and according to the same law, the one were saved and the other not? And if it be not impossible, as has already been proved, that the flesh be regenerated, what is the distinction on the ground of which the soul is saved and the body not? Do they make God a grudging God? But He is good, and will have all to be saved.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:16
verses.text: And by God and His proclamation, not only has your soul heard and believed on Jesus Christ, and with it the flesh, but both were washed, and both wrought righteousness.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:17
verses.text: They make God, then ungrateful and unjust, if, while both believe on Him, He desires to save one and not the other.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:18
verses.text: Well, they say, but the soul is incorruptible, being a part of God and inspired by Him, and therefore He desires to save what is peculiarly His own and akin to Himself; but the flesh is corruptible, and not from Him, as the soul is.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:19
verses.text: Then what thanks are due to Him, and what manifestation of His power and goodness is it, if He purposed to save what is by nature saved and exists as a part of Himself? For it had its salvation from itself; so that in saving the soul, God does no great thing.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:20
verses.text: For to be saved is its natural destiny, because it is a part of Himself, being His inspiration.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:21
verses.text: But no thanks are due to one who saves what is his own; for this is to save himself.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:22
verses.text: For he who saves a part himself, saves himself by his own means, lest he become defective in that part; and this is not the act of a good man.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:23
verses.text: For not even when a man does good to his children and offspring, does one call him a good man; for even the most savage of the wild beasts do so, and indeed willingly endure death, if need be, for the sake of their cubs.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:24
verses.text: But if a man were to perform the same acts in behalf of his slaves, that man would justly be called good.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:25
verses.text: Wherefore the Saviour also taught us to love our enemies, since, says He, what thank have ye? So that He has shown us that it is a good work not only to love those that are begotten of Him, but also those that are without.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 8:26
verses.text: And what He enjoins upon us, He Himself first of all does.

chapters.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 9

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 9 — The resurrection of Christ proves that the body rises.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 9:2
verses.text: If He had no need of the flesh, why did He heal it? And what is most forcible of all, He raised the dead.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 9:3
verses.text: Why? Was it not to show what the resurrection should be? How then did He raise the dead? Their souls or their bodies? Manifestly both.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 9:4
verses.text: If the resurrection were only spiritual, it was requisite that He, in raising the dead, should show the body lying apart by itself, and the soul living apart by itself.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 9:5
verses.text: But now He did not do so, but raised the body, confirming in it the promise of life.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 9:6
verses.text: Why did He rise in the flesh in which He suffered, unless to show the resurrection of the flesh? And wishing to confirm this, when His disciples did not know whether to believe He had truly risen in the body, and were looking upon Him and doubting, He said to them, "Ye have not yet faith, see that it is I;" and He let them handle Him, and showed them the prints of the nails in His hands.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 9:7
verses.text: And when they were by every kind of proof persuaded that it was Himself, and in the body, they asked Him to eat with them, that they might thus still more accurately ascertain that He had in verity risen bodily; and He did eat honey-comb and fish.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 9:8
verses.text: And when He had thus shown them that there is truly a resurrection of the flesh, wishing to show them this also, that it is not impossible for flesh to ascend into heaven (as He had said that our dwelling-place is in heaven), "He was taken up into heaven while they beheld," as He was in the flesh.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 9:9
verses.text: If, therefore, after all that has been said, any one demand demonstration of the resurrection, he is in no respect different from the Sadducees, since the resurrection of the flesh is the power of God, and, being above all reasoning, is established by faith, and seen in works.

chapters.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 10

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 10 — The body saved, and will therefore rise.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 10:2
verses.text: The resurrection is a resurrection of the flesh which died.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 10:3
verses.text: For the spirit dies not; the soul is in the body, and without a soul it cannot live.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 10:4
verses.text: The body, when the soul forsakes it, is not.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 10:5
verses.text: For the body is the house of the soul; and the soul the house of the spirit.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 10:6
verses.text: These three, in all those who cherish a sincere hope and unquestioning faith in God, will be saved.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 10:7
verses.text: Considering, therefore, even such arguments as are suited to this world, and finding that, even according to them, it is not impossible that the flesh be regenerated; and seeing that, besides all these proofs, the Saviour in the whole Gospel shows that there is salvation for the flesh, why do we any longer endure those unbelieving and dangerous arguments, and fail to see that we are retrograding when we listen to such an argument as this: that the soul is immortal, but the body mortal, and incapable of being revived? For this we used to hear from Pythagoras and Plato,  even before we learned the truth.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 10:8
verses.text: If then the Saviour said this, and proclaimed salvation to the soul alone, what new thing, beyond what we heard from Pythagoras and Plato and all their band, did He bring us? But now He has come proclaiming the glad tidings of a new and strange hope to men.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 10:9
verses.text: For indeed it was a strange and new thing for God to promise that He would not keep incorruption in incorruption, but would make corruption incorruption.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 10:10
verses.text: But because the prince of wickedness could in no other way corrupt the truth, he sent forth his apostles (evil men who introduced pestilent doctrines), choosing them from among those who crucified our Saviour; and these men bore the name of the Saviour, but did the works of him that sent them, through whom the name itself has been spoken against.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 10:11
verses.text: But if the flesh do not rise, why is it also guarded, and why do we not rather suffer it to indulge its desires? Why do we not imitate physicians, who, it is said, when they get a patient that is despaired of and incurable, allow him to indulge his desires? For they know that he is dying; and this indeed those who hate the flesh surely do, casting it out of its inheritance, so far as they can; for on this account they also despise it, because it is shortly to become a corpse.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Fragments and Lost Works on the Resurrection 10:12
verses.text: But if our physician Christ, God, having rescued us from our desires, regulates our flesh with His own wise and temperate rule, it is evident that He guards it from sins because it possesses a hope of salvation, as physicians do not suffer men whom they hope to save to indulge in what pleasures they please.
